description: Unknown. Probably from US Southern dialectal hassle (“to pant, breathe noisily”), possibly from haste +‎ -le (frequentative suffix).

adjectives.description: hassle (comparative more hassle, superlative most hassle)

entries.meaning: Trouble, bother, unwanted annoyances or problems.
examples: I went through a lot of hassle to be the first to get a ticket.

entries.meaning: An action which is not worth the difficulty involved.

verbs.description: hassle (third-person singular simple present hassles, present participle hassling, simple past and past participle hassled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To trouble, to bother, to annoy.
examples: The unlucky boy was hassled by a gang of troublemakers on his way home.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pick a fight or start an argument with.
(military, aviation, slang) To engage in a mock dogfight.
examples: Likewise, “hassling”—mock dogfighting—was strictly forbidden, and so naturally young fighter jocks could hardly wait to go up in, say, a pair of F–100s and start the duel by making a pass at each other at 800 miles an hour,  […]
